context: <a5_0><b10_0><b11_0><b14_0><b15_0><b16_0><b18_0>Sanskrit<b18_0/><b16_0/><b15_0/><b14_0/><b11_0/><b10_0/><a5_0/> (/ˈsænskrɪt/; Sanskrit: saṃskṛtam [səmskr̩t̪əm] or saṃskṛta, originally saṃskṛtā vāk, "refined speech") is the primary sacred language of <a0_0>Hinduism<a0_0/>, a philosophical language in Buddhism, Hinduism, <a3_0>Sikhism<a3_0/> and Jainism, and a literary language that was in use as a <a6_0>lingua franca<a6_0/> in <b17_0>Greater <a7_0>India<b17_0/><a7_0/>. It is a standardised dialect of <a4_0><a8_0>Old Indo-Aryan<a8_0/><a4_0/>, originating as <a9_0>Vedic Sanskrit<a9_0/> and tracing its linguistic ancestry back to Proto-Indo-Iranian and Proto-Indo-European. Today it is listed as one of the <a1_0><b12_0>22<b12_0/><a1_0/> scheduled languages of India and is an official language of the state of <a2_0><b13_0>Uttarakhand<b13_0/><a2_0/>. As one of the oldest Indo-European languages for which substantial written documentation exists, Sanskrit holds a prominent position in <b19_0>Indo-European studies<b19_0/>.
